questions.text: Which is elevated in pyridoxal phosphate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, is a required coenzyme for kynureninase, an enzyme in the tryptophan degradation pathway. In PLP deficiency, the pathway is blocked, leading to accumulation and urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid after tryptophan load.

Tryptophan metabolism -

  • Tryptophan is degraded to amphibolic intermediates via the kynurenine-anthranilate pathway.
  • Tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase opens the indole ring, incorporates molecular oxygen, and forms N-formylkynurenine.
  • Hydrolytic removal of the formyl group of N-formylkynurenine, catalysed by kynurenine formylase, produces kynurenine.
  • Since kynureninase requires pyridoxal phosphate, excretion of xanthurenate in response to a tryptophan load is diagnostic of vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • 5-HIAA is elevated in carcinoid syndrome (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Xanthurenic acid is elevated in vitamin B6 deficiency, especially after a tryptophan load.
  • PLP is essential for tryptophan metabolism via the kynurenine pathway.

Explanation:

Dopamine is a catecholamine synthesised from tyrosine, a non-essential aromatic amino acid.

  • The conversion involves two key enzymatic steps: hydroxylation of tyrosine to DOPA (by tyrosine hydroxylase) and decarboxylation of DOPA to dopamine by DOPA decarboxylase, which is a pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)-dependent enzyme.
  • Tyrosine is responsible for the synthesis of -
    • Melanin
    • Thyroxine hormones (T4 & T3)
    • Catecholamines (Dopamine, Epinephrine, Norepinephrine)
  • Dopamine synthesis pathway:
    1. Tyrosine → DOPA (via tyrosine hydroxylase)
    2. DOPA → Dopamine (via DOPA decarboxylase, requires PLP)
  • This pathway occurs in neuronal and adrenal medullary cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tryptophan (Option A): Precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin, not dopamine.

Threonine (Option B): Degraded to propionyl-CoA or glycine - not involved in catecholamine synthesis.

Lysine (Option D): A ketogenic amino acid involved in carnitine biosynthesis, unrelated to dopamine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tyrosine is the precursor of dopamine, via DOPA as an intermediate.
  • DOPA decarboxylase requires vitamin B6 (PLP) for activity.

choices.text: Limiting the substrate for deficient enzyme
Giving the missing amino acid by diet

questions.text: In Phenylketonuria the main aim of first line therapy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The primary therapeutic goal in Phenylketonuria (PKU) is to restrict phenylalanine intake through diet. This limits the accumulation of phenylalanine, the substrate for the deficient enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, and prevents neurotoxic effects such as mental retardation.

Phenylketonuria:-

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disorder. Hyperphenylalaninemias arise from defects in -
    • Phenylalanine hydroxylase (type I, classic phenylketonuria (PKU), frequency 1 in 10,000 births)
    • Dihydrobiopterin reductase(type II and III)
    • Dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis(type IV and V)
  • Alternative catabolites are excreted. A diet low in phenylalanine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU.
  • DNA probes facilitate prenatal diagnosis of defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase or dihydrobiopterin reductase.
  • Deficiency leads to hyperphenylalaninemia and accumulation of phenyl ketones, causing:
    • Mental retardation
    • Seizures
    • Hypopigmentation
  • Treatment of Classical PKU:
  • A low-phenylalanine diet
  • Administration of large neutral amino acids may help reduce Phe transport into the brain.
  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) supplementation in responsive cases
  • Screening:
  • Tandem mass spectrometry is the standard method
  • Urine ferric chloride test (FeCl3) is an older screening tool (green colour with phenylpyruvate)

Explanation of Other Options:

Replacement of the defective enzyme (Option A): Enzyme replacement is not used in PKU. The issue is addressed through dietary management.

Replacement of the deficient product (Option B): Tyrosine (the product of PAH) may be supplemented, but this is not the primary goal of therapy.

Giving the missing amino acid by diet (Option D): Tyrosine may become conditionally essential in PKU, but the main strategy is to restrict phenylalanine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dietary phenylalanine restriction is the cornerstone of PKU management to prevent cognitive deficits.
  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency diverts phenylalanine to toxic metabolites.

questions.text: : A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray spine shows calcification of IV disk. On adding Benedict's reagent to urine, it gives a greenish brown precipitate and a blue-black supernatant fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad of darkening urine on standing, ochronosis (bluish-black pigmentation of connective tissues), and calcification of intervertebral discs with positive Benedict's test suggests alkaptonuria, caused by homogentisate oxidase deficiency.

Alkaptonuria:

  • It is an autosomal recessiveinborn error of metabolism.
  • Biochemical defect - Homogentisate Oxidase deficiencyleads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate), which polymerises to form Alkapton bodies.
  • Clinical presentation -
    • Normal Life till the 3rd or 4th decade.
    • Urine darkens on exposure to airis the only manifestation in children.
    • In adults, Ochronosis: Alkapton bodies in intervertebral disk, cartilage of nose, pinna, etc.
    • No mental retardation
  • Laboratory Diagnosis -
    • Alkalization increases the darkening of urine.
    • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is a reducing agent.
    • Ferric Chloride test positive.
    • Silver Nitrate Test positive.
  • Treatment-
    • Mainly symptomatic
    • Avoid a high-protein diet (rich in phenylalanine & tyrosine)
    • Vitamin C may slow ochronosis progression

Explanation of Other Options:

Phenylketonuria (Option A): PAH deficiency; presents with mental retardation, fair complexion, and musty odour- not ochronosis or positive Benedict's. Tyrosine becomes essential; diagnosis via tandem MS in newborn screening.

Tyrosinemia type 2 (Option C): Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency; presents with eye lesions (keratitis), skin lesions (painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis), and intellectual disability- not intervertebral calcification.

Argininosuccinic aciduria (Option D): Urea cycle disorder; presents with hyperammonemia, vomiting, and lethargy in infancy- no dark urine or connective tissue pigmentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Alkaptonuria presents with ochronosis, darkening urine, and intervertebral disc calcification.
  • It is due to homogentisate oxidase deficiency, leading to homogentisic acid accumulation.

questions.text: Screening test for phenylketonuria from urine used for newborn infants is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The FeCl3 test is a classic urine screening test used to detect phenylpyruvate in the urine of infants suspected of having phenylketonuria (PKU). A green colour indicates the presence of phenylpyruvate, a byproduct of excess phenylalanine metabolism.

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH)
  • Leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its transaminated product phenylpyruvate.
  • FeCl3 (Ferric chloride) test:
    • Detects phenylpyruvate in urine.
    • Produces a green
    • Less reliable and is now largely replaced by tandem mass spectrometry in many countries.
  • Timing:
    • Phenylalanine elevation in blood may not be detectable until 3-4 days postpartum.
    • False positives can occur in premature infants due to immature liver enzyme systems.

Explanation of Other Options:

Benedict test (Option A): Detects reducing sugars, not specific for phenylalanine or phenylpyruvate. Used in conditions like galactosemia or alkaptonuria.

FIGLU test (Option C): Used for diagnosing folic acid deficiency by measuring formiminoglutamic acid in urine after a histidine load.

Turbidometry (Option D): A nonspecific technique used in various clinical assays; not the traditional test for PKU.

Key Takeaways:

  • The FeCl3 test is the classical screening method for detecting phenylpyruvate in urine in suspected PKU
  • Modern screening programs prefer tandem mass spectrometry for accuracy.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic defects is seen in Type I Tyrosinemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type I tyrosinemia (also called tyrosinosis) is caused by a deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase, which leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites resulting in liver failure, renal dysfunction, and a risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

  • Tyrosine degradation pathway:
    Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate → Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate → Fumarylacetoacetate → Fumarate + Acetoacetate
  • Type I Tyrosinemia:
    • Enzyme defect: Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH)
    • Accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone (toxic)
    • Clinical features: Liver failure, renal tubular dysfunction, cabbage-like odour
    • Treatment: Diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine, NTBC (nitisinone)
  • Untreated acute and chronic tyrosinosis leads to death from liver failure. Therapy employs a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tyrosine Transaminase (Option A): Alternate name for Tyrosine aminotransferase, which is defective in Type II tyrosinemia. Converts tyrosine to p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate.

4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate Hydroxylase (Option C): Defective in neonatal tyrosinemia. Converts p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisate.

Tyrosine Aminotransferase (Option D): Another name for Tyrosine transaminase; defective in Type II tyrosinemia. First step in tyrosine degradation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Type I tyrosinemia is due to fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency and can lead to fatal liver failure without early intervention.

questions.text: The terminal products of Phenylalanine metabolism are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phenylalanine metabolism leads to the formation of fumarate, acetate, and acetyl-CoA. Oxaloacetate is not derived from phenylalanine; hence, it is the correct answer.

  • Phenylalanine is first converted to tyrosine.
  • Tyrosine undergoes multiple enzymatic steps to form homogentisate, which is further broken down into maleylacetoacetate and fumarylacetoacetate.
  • Fumarylacetoacetate splits into:
    • Fumarate → Glucogenic (Option A ruled out)
    • Acetoacetate → Ketogenic
  • Acetoacetate gives rise to:
    • Acetyl-CoA (Option B ruled out)
    • Acetate (Option D ruled out)

Explanation:

Tyrosinase is the key enzyme required for melanin biosynthesis; its deficiency leads to albinism.

  • Albinism is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by defective melanin production.
  • Tyrosinase catalyses the initial steps in melanin synthesis, including the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA and subsequently to dopaquinone.
  • In albinism, tyrosinase activity is either absent or significantly reduced, impairing melanin formation.
  • Clinical manifestations include:
    • Hypopigmented skin, hair, and eyes.
    • Increased sensitivity to UV radiation predisposes to melanomas.
    • Ocular findings: photophobia, nystagmus, hypopigmented fundus, decreased visual acuity.

Explanation of other options:

Tyrosine hydroxylase (Option B): Enzyme involved in catecholamine synthesis; not related to melanin production.

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (Option C): Converts phenylalanine to tyrosine; its deficiency causes phenylketonuria, not albinism.

Homogentisate oxidase (Option D): Deficiency causes alkaptonuria, which presents with dark urine and ochronosis.

Key Takeaways:

Tyrosinase is the essential enzyme for melanin production; its deficiency causes albinism.

questions.text: Mousy body odour in PKU is due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The characteristic "mousy" or "musty" body odour in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation and excretion of phenylacetate, a byproduct of phenylalanine metabolism.

  • Phenylketonuria is caused by a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine.
  • In the absence of this enzyme, phenylalanine is transaminated to phenylpyruvate.
  • Phenylpyruvate is then metabolised into phenylacetate and phenyllactate.
  • Phenylacetate is responsible for the mousy/musty body odour observed in PKU patients.
  • Excess phenylalanine and its derivatives are neurotoxic and cause irreversible cognitive impairment if untreated.
  • Clinical Manifestations of Phenylketonuria (PKU) -
    • The affected infant is normal, at Profoundmental retardationdevelops gradually if the infant remains untreated. Cognitive delay may not be evident for the 1st few months.
    • Some may have a seborrheic or eczematoid rash, which is usually mild and disappears as the child grows older.
    • These children have an unpleasant odour of phenylaceticacid, which has been described as musty or mousey.
  • Early diagnosis and dietary restriction of phenylalanine can prevent neurological damage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Phenylalanine (Option A): Aromatic essential amino acid; substrate that accumulates in PKU but does not directly cause the mousy odour. Elevated phenylalanine is neurotoxic, but odour arises from its metabolic products.

Phenylbutazone (Option C): NSAID used for inflammatory conditions; not a metabolite of phenylalanine. Structurally unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism and not associated with PKU.

Phenylacetylglutamine (Option D): Conjugate excreted in urea cycle disorders and some hyperammonemic states; not characteristic of PKU. Typically seen in alternative nitrogen excretion pathways, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid can be converted into a vitamin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tryptophan serves as a precursor for the synthesis of niacin (vitamin B3) in the human body through the kynurenine pathway.

  • Approximately 60 mg of tryptophan yields 1 mg of niacin.
  • This conversion is important in preventing pellagra in conditions of low dietary niacin.
  • The pathway involves several enzymes and cofactors such as PLP (pyridoxal phosphate), iron, and FAD.
  • Impairment in this conversion can occur due to deficiency of vitamin B6, iron, or riboflavin, or due to genetic disorders like Hartnup disease or carcinoid syndrome.
  • Niacin and tryptophan are interdependent in maintaining adequate NAD+ synthesis for energy metabolism.
  • The tryptophan-to-niacin pathway also explains the occurrence of pellagra-like symptoms in vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: : Which of the following would not act as a source of glycine by transamination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspartate does not serve as a substrate in transamination reactions to form glycine. Glycine is formed by transamination reactions involving glyoxylate, glutamate, or alanine, not aspartate.

  • Glycine can be synthesised by transamination of glyoxylate using either glutamate or alanine as the amino group donor.
  • Other important sources of glycine include serine (via serine hydroxymethyltransferase) and choline (through several oxidation and demethylation steps).

Pathways of Glycine Synthesis:

Explanation of other options:

Alanine (Option A): The Amino group from alanine can be transferred to glyoxylate to form glycine via alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase.

Glutamate (Option C): Major amino group donor in transamination; donates amino group to glyoxylate, forming glycine.

Glyoxylate (Option D): Key keto acid that accepts amino groups to generate glycine; highly active in hepatic metabolism.
